page.title: 08FARMING, KIRKBY UNDERWOOD
page.content: Most farmers are tenants renting their farms from private landlords. Farms rarely come up for let. Approximately 90% of the land is under plough with 10% down to permanent grass. The mostly chalky bolder clay soil grows good quality cereals. Crops grown include winter wheat, winter barley and oats with rotational break crops of oil seed rape, tic beans and a small quantity of potatoes and seeds for hay. Animals kept are pigs, sheep and store cattle; no dairy herds and no poultry. Some farms form part of a larger unit, units range from 200 to 1000 acres. Each farmer owns a combine harvester, a corn dryer and modern high-powered tractors plus numerous other tools. Hedges and dykes are kept neat and tidy, the work mainly undertaken by contractors.
